abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings show a highly satisfactory
            project outcome, highly likely sustainability, and
            substantial institutional development impacts, achieved
            through a highly satisfactory Bank performance, and a
            satisfactory Borrower performance. Regardless of success,
            some of the lessons of experience provide the following
            findings, and suggestions. In this project, the first type
            of risk seemed mitigated by the fact that some basic
            pre-concession studies, including a concession modeling, had
            already been implemented under the previous urban transport
            project, and, to mitigate the risk of political opposition,
            namely by the unions, dated covenants for issuing
            pre-qualification documents and concession awarding, were
            included in the loan agreement. However, it is not
            sufficient to include dated covenants in the loan agreement;
            rather a concrete and irreversible political step in this
            direction should already be given before project
            negotiation. Furthermore, creating a new and formal entity,
            to which the constituting agencies have to cede some of
            their authority and powers, requires more than the presence
            of a "collaborative environment". It needs an
            understanding at the political level, currently expected to
            happen because both the State and the Municipality of Sao
            Paulo found a common cause in the integration of the
            municipal buses with the metro. Regarding the formal
            integration with the Minibus System which provides services,
            also create a strong competition for regular public
            transport operators, and so put the viability of less
            polluting and more space efficient systems at stake; a fight
            against this phenomenon is no easy battle. The reason for
            this success lies in the nature of the solution, which did
            not consist in repression of the informal services, but
            their constructive inclusion, as much as possible, into the
            formal urban transport system.
